What is a zkSNARK?
Well, so, it's an argument,
that is it's a proof,
but one whose validity depends on some cryptographic assumption.
Um, and it's an argument of knowledge.
Which means you can use it to prove, roughly speaking,
that you know a secret and, it's zero knowledge.
Meaning that when you use it to prove that you know a secret,
you don't reveal anything about that secret.
Um, now the proof is succinct,
meaning that it's short and it's non-interactive.
So it can just be written down and then later somebody can come and read it.
It doesn't require any kind of conversation.
And finally, we are concerned about publicly verifiable proofs.
Meaning anyone who reads the proof,
will be convinced of its validity.
So, ah, when we compare these different kinds of
SNARKs there are at least five questions that we can ask.
One is how big is the proof?
We said it was small, succinct,
but some kinds of zkSNARKs are smaller than others and
generally speaking argument systems may or may not be succinct.
Proof size is important.
For example, if you're gonna be sending the proofs over a network,
or if you're going to be storing many proofs for a long time.
Another question is, how hard is it to generate a proof?
That is how much time does it take to write down the contents of the proof?
And relatedly, how much time does it take to check the proof?
Okay? And throughout the talk you're going to see these a script 'P',and script 'V'.
Those refer to the prover, and the verifier.
The entity that generates the proof, and the entity that checks the proof.
Okay. So, remember the validity of these proofs since their arguments really,
depend on some cryptographic assumption.
So another question we can ask is,
what is that cryptographic assumption?
Er, we might care about this because as you would guess the,
the cryptographic community has reason to believe that some assumptions,
are better than others, maybe because they've been battle-tested for longer.
And finally, some zkSNARKs including the ones, ah,
that are currently most widely deployed like in Zcash require a trusted setup.
Meaning, that somebody has to run
an expensive one time computation and you can only believe a proof is valid,
if you trust the entity or entities that ran that setup computation.
So you can see already this is a big design space and every kind of zkSNARK and
every kind of zero knowledge proof system more generally
gives some different mix of these properties.

So when we talk about general purpose proof systems,
usually we mean proof systems for NP languages.
So what that means is there is some relation R,
and we can think of that as a computation that takes some values,
and then returns True or False.
And the values, are an input X,
from the verifier, and a witness W, from the approver.
And we can think of the witness as a secret,
that the prover knows and R the relation as
a computation that checks whether the witness is somehow,
correct for the verifier's input.
And at a very high level,
these systems all operate by turning
the witness checking computation into a sort of two different computations.
One, that's the verifier's job,
and one, that's the prover's job.
So we can think of this as sort of happening in
two stages which we'll call the front end and the back end.
Now in the front end,
we convert the witness checking computation into an arithmetic circuit.
Which is to say a generalized Boolean circuit,
where we can think of AND Gates as becoming
multiplication and OR Gates as becoming addition.
And the front end constructs this arithmetic circuit such that
its satisfiability is tantamount to
the correct execution of the witness checking computation.
Okay? Then the back end, applies proving machinery,
which is some combination of complexity theoretic and cryptographic objects,
to produce approver and a verifier computation.
Em, so such that a valid proof establishes that the circuit is satisfied.
Which by any implication in the front end
establishes that the witness checking computation was run correctly.

I've been talking about different kinds of zero knowledge proof systems and,
and really what I've been referring to is that,
that proof machinery in the back end.

So Hyrax is built on a completely different thing called
an interactive proof which is essentially a probabilistic cross-examination.
And we make these interactive proofs zero knowledge
using techniques of Ben-Or et al and Cramer and Damg√•rd.
But as we'll see naively applying those techniques results in poor performance.
So in Hyrax we also include several refinements which result in order of magnitudes
improvement in both verifier time and proof

So the high level idea in Hyrax is,
that in an interactive proof,
the verifier sending questions and the prover is sending answers to those questions.
And what we're gonna do is replace all the answers that the prover
sends with cryptographic commitments to the answers.
And then the prover is gonna help the verifier,
um to check that the contents of the commitment are actually
a message that would have been valid in the sort of
underlying interactive proof without revealing anything else.
Um, so to review,
let's take a look at a cryptographic commitment.
So in a cryptographic commitment scheme we have a sender that computes
a commitment to a message and then it sends the commitment to a receiver.
The later the sender can open the commitment um,
and then reveal the message inside and convince the receiver that
the message that's revealed is consistent with the com- with the- with the um,
um commitment that was sent earlier.
So generally speaking, commitment schemes have two properties that we care about.
Hiding means that the commitment reveals nothing about the message
inside and binding means that the sender can't lie when it tries to open that commitment.
It can't decide, well I really wanted to send this other message,
so I'm gonna do that instead because it'll get caught cheating.
So Hyrax uses special class of commitments that have sort of a third, sorry,
they have sort of a third property a linear homomorphism,
which means there's some operator that we can
use essentially to add two commitments together.
So when we do that,
we get a new commitment that has inside of it,
a message that's the sum of the two.
And from that you can get sort of scaling by a- by
some constant factor because you can just add the same message to itself many times.
Okay, so the other thing that Hyrax builds on is an interactive proof
and specifically one due to Goldwasser, Kalai and Rothblum.
This is an interactive proof for layered arithmetic circuit evaluation,
which means that the inputs to the circuit feed one set of
gates and those- that the outputs from those gates feed a second set,
the outputs from those feed a third et cetera.
Um, so to start the proof the verifier gives some inputs to the prover and then
the prover is gonna evaluate the arithmetic circuit and produce some output y,
that it's gonna send to the verifier.
Now the verifier and the prover start to interact.
So first the verifier is gonna construct
a polynomial that relates the purported output that's y,
to the last layer of gates in the circuit.
Then it's gonna engage the prover in what's called a sum-check protocol.
This is sort of a foundational interactive proof.
And the result of that sum-check protocol is
a claim about the second last layer of the circuit.
Now in some sense that's not good enough
because the verifier can't check that very easily.
So what do the verifier and prover do?
They-they continue to interact.
So now we run another sum-check and we get a claim without the prior layer.
And we keep doing that and eventually we get
a claim whose truth is related to the inputs to the computation.
Now in a non-zero knowledge version of GKR, this would be it,
we would be done because the verifier has
those inputs and it can just check that claim directly.
But in Zero knowledge we need to make two modifications.
So the first one as I said earlier,
is that the prover  is going to replace all of its messages in
the sum-check invocations with commitments to those messages.
And the second, and this one's a little more complicated,
is that we need to give the verifier some way to check that final statement in the proof.
And remember, the verifier never gets to see the witness.
And since this is a witness checking computation,
somehow the inputs have to encode the witness.
So the verifier certainly can't check that directly.
So what's it gonna do? Well, we're going to use what we
call a polynomial commitment scheme.
So the the final check that the verifier needs to
do is just evaluating a polynomial that we'll call tilde m.
And this polynomial encodes both the input and the witness.
Now to run that check,
the prover will send a commitment to the verifier at the start of the protocol.
So before any interaction happens.
Okay then the prover and the verifier are gonna run
the interactive proof that we just saw on the previous slide.
And at the end the prover is just going to make a claim, it's going to say,
"here the evaluation that you really want is this one, is this value here."
And finally the prover and the verifier are going to engage in an- in
an additional protocol that convinces
the verifier that the output that the prover just claimed,
is consistent with the commitments
that the prover sent at the beginning of the protocol.
So um, Hyrax uses
a new polynomial commitment scheme for multi linear polynomials which is what m tilde is.

we can already compute a vector matrix vector product just by using that homomorphism.
Okay, but that's inefficient.

the polynomial is linear in the size of the witness.
Right. So as the witness gets bigger,
it scales linearly and we'd rather scale sub linearly.
Um, so to sidestep that problem,
we're going to follow an idea due to Jens Groth who uses
multi commitment schemes to commit to each row of the matrix.
So what's a multi commitment?
Well it's a commitment where the message inside is a vector.
And if we use the Pedersen commitment then what we
get is a multi commitment that has a vector wise homomorphism.
So if we have two commitments,
two vectors and we use the add- addition operator on them,
what we get is a commitment to a new vector that's
the sum vector wise of the previous two.
